clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy and Safety of Expandable Spacer in the Treatment of Degenerative Disc Disease Using the Minimally Invasive Transforaminal Lumbar Interbody Fusion Surgical Approach
clinical_study.official_title: Study of an Expandable Interbody Device for the Lumbar Spine

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of CALIBER expandable spacer for the treatment of degenerative disc disease. Radiographic outcomes, intra-operative parameters, clinical outcomes, and patient satisfaction will be obtained from patients in this 2 year follow-up clinical study.

detailed_description.textblock: Patients will be followed-up at 3weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 12 and 24 months with X-rays and questionnaires to determine their satisfaction, healing, fusion and return to work status

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.description: X-rays and patient questionnaires to be done/completed

secondary_outcome.description: Questionnaires on health and healing status will be completed by patients at all follow-up visits

arm_group.description: 1 or 2 levels of DDD between L2 and S1, treated with transforaminal interbody fusion

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- DDD at 1 or 2 levels between L2 and S1
- Between 18 and 80 years of age
- Unresponsiveness to documented non-surgical treatment modalities for a minimum of six months
- Ability to provide a signed Informed Consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Trauma at level(s) to be fused
- Previous documentation of osteopenia, osteoporosis, or osteomalacia to a degree that spinal instrumentation would be contraindicated
- Immunosuppressive disorder
- History of substance abuse
- Any known allergy to a metal alloy

facility.name: South Florida Spine Institute at Mt Sinai Medical Center
